stem: The labor and delivery nurse is managing four clients in active labor. Based on the documentation, match each FHR pattern to the priority nursing action.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
Patient A: G1P0; 8cm dilated. FHR shows early decelerations mirroring contractions.
Patient B: G3P2; 6cm dilated. FHR shows recurrent late decelerations (present on >50% of contractions in 20 min).
Patient C: G1P0; 4cm dilated. FHR shows intermittent variable decelerations with normal baseline.
Patient D: G2P1; 5cm dilated. FHR shows a persistent baseline of 180 bpm for the last 30 minutes.

tabs.title: Intrapartum Assessment & Intervention Log
tabs.content:

rationale.correct: Early decelerations (r1) are normal head compressions and only require observation (c1). Late decelerations (r2) require immediate intrauterine resuscitation (O2, fluids, side-lying) (c2). Variable decelerations (r3) require a position change to relieve cord pressure (c3). Fetal tachycardia (r4) usually indicates maternal fever or dehydration (c4).
clinicalPearls: Late decelerations indicate uteroplacental insufficiency and require immediate intervention.
Early decelerations are benign and reflect fetal head compression.
Variable decelerations often indicate umbilical cord compression; repositioning the mother is a key intervention.

questionTrap.trap: Assuming all decelerations require immediate intervention.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Differentiate between early, late, and variable decelerations and understand the underlying cause of each to determine the appropriate intervention.

mnemonic.title: VEAL CHOP
mnemonic.expansion: V-C (Variable-Cord Compression). E-H (Early-Head Compression). A-O (Acceleration-Okay). L-P (Late-Placental Insufficiency).
